description.narrative: An integrated, peaceful and democratically governed Africa dirven by its citizens and playing a pivotal role in global political and economic diplomacy.
The African Union Commission's Department for Political Affairs, pooled funds for Election and Governance (2014 - 2017).

sector.narrative: Public sector policy and administrative management

Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative: The Swedish support as part of the Joint Financial Arrangement amounted to 32 MSEK and was directed to the AUC Political Affairs Department with 14 MSEK allocated to the pooled fund for Governance and Humanitarian Affairs Program, and 18 MSEK to the pooled fund for the Elections Programme. Other donors contributing were Denmark, the Netherlands and the UK. The Swedish payment for 2017 was never released (MSEK 9,5), due to delayed submissions and slow consumption rate, and after the expiry of the agreement AUC reimbursed 5,077,382 SEK of unused funds. The total grant agreement eventually amounted to 17,422,618 SEK. Altogether AUC/DPA reimbursed 2,018,858 USD to the respective donors. Reporting has reflected a slow implementation rate and delays already from the beginning, reflected in the first annual report. Quality of narrative reporting has been assessed as poor, too focused on activities and lacking analysis of reporting. Donors have also given feed-back on the lack of access to some of the documents referred to in the narrative reporting. The reporting includes achievements in terms of countries engaging in ratification process of the African Charter on Democracy, Elections and Governance; the putting in place of reporting systems under the same charter; no of member states submitting reports to the African Charter on Decentralization, Local Governance and Local Development; establishment of the Pan African Institute for Human Rights in Arusha; Deployment of Human Rights Experts providing capacity the NHRIs at national level and providing reporting; Election observation missions including pre-election assessments, high-level political missions and short term election observation missions; and election support methodology development. In addition, training and capacity development is reporting, amongst others for AU election observation members and for national election management bodies and CSOs. The budget has been used for staff, meetings, sensitization, trainings, development of guidelines, policy briefs and consultative technical support. Difficulties and challenges referred to in the reporting for 2017 (the last annual report) regard lack of political will by member states, limited human resource capacity and time constraints. No particular generic success factors are mentioned. On detailed level, progress on the establishment of a PanAfrican Human Rights Institute in Arusha is mentioned as well as progress with a draft AU policy on transitional justice. In the election area, individual missions and country-level contributions are presented as successful. In particular the long-term missions were found useful, since they could contribute to better briefings to the AU Peace and Security Council and inform decision-making.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
